posts.name: Ian
posts.cooked:
I’m a member of my team’s programming team, (with no official coding mentor) and I’m having some difficulty utilizing vision to auto-align our robot to April Tags. We use YAGSL as our main code base and we would ideally want to use this feature in both Tele-Operated and Autonomous modes. Let me know if you need any further information!

A link to our code is provided: GitHub - FRC1027/1027-2025: 2025 Season

Any help/assistance is greatly appreciated!

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked:
How are you attempting to do it right now? When you say auto align, do you mean driving and aligning, or just angling? I am from team 1466, and we currently use pathplanner Pathfinding system. You just give it a goal end pose with a heading and path constraints (speed, acelleration, etc) and it will autonomously navigate there while avoiding obstacles. Our code is not very clean right now, but if you would like to see it here it is:

GitHub - FRC1466/robot-code-2025 Contribute to FRC1466/robot-code-2025 development by creating an account on GitHub.

Contribute to FRC1466/robot-code-2025 development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked: We have recently began work on switching to auto pathing during autonomous and teleop, but we mainly run it during teleop right now.

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: We were having trouble getting to align reliably to the right pose. It wasn’t consistent. Have your guys had this issue. How did u fix it?

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked: When you say to the right pose, do you literally just mean it would be off laterally? Can you upload a video of whats happening? We use photonvision with two cameras, both on the front of our robot. Is it consistently off, or just sometimes?

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: Sometimes translation sometimes rotation. I don’t have a video at the moment. We use 3 cameras and 2 pi’s running photon vision and we have global pose estimation. But the path planner autos just isn’t consistent

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked:
Huh, that is pretty strange. We have nearly perfect pathing, with less cameras. Can you describe the location of your cameras? Something that could help is removing any cameras on the back of the robot, just leaving a few to see the tags on the reef. This will allow for slightly more acurrate movements when scoring, since the estimate close up will be much more correct. It doesn’t seem like you guys use pathplanner for your pathfinding, but a custom solution instead? I could just be looking at the wrong code. Since you guys seem to use pathplanner this year, I would recommend looking into their pathfinding system:

https://pathplanner.dev/pplib-pathfinding.html#advantagekit-compatibility

If you guys are already doing that and consistency is the only problem, I would look at where the robot thinks it is. If it believes it is in the right pose even though it isn’t in real life, then there is some innacuracy in the vision. If it knows it is in the wrong spot, then there is most likely a problem with the pathfinding code itself.

This is a video of our pathfinding in action for reference. While it does occasionally miss (and it has been missing less and less in practice) it still would normally be consistently off and just need to have one of the setpoints adjusted. Our codebase definitely is not the cleanest right now, but probably the easiest place to look for this would be our branch here:

geeked-up-autos

Contribute to FRC1466/robot-code-2025 development by creating an account on GitHub.

This includes the auto pathing in the file Util/Pathfind.java. It is referenced both in robot container through configureKeybinds() (for teleop) and in the Util/PathfindingAutoCommands.java file you could see our autonomous implementation as well.

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked: I’ve found it very helpful to publish the pose estimates and the robot’s estimated pose out to SmartDashboard and have AdvantageScope visualize them. Compard where it thinks it is in 3d space to where it actually is, making sure that everything lines up nice, then drive it around for a bit in teleop, see how it tracks, learn how to reject errant readings and set your standard deviations as you feed in vision measurements.
